semantic_title: Iatrogenic Injuries - Use of Complication Codes Instead of Injury Codes
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > b. Coding of Injuries > 3) Iatrogenic injuries

content.full_text: Injury codes from Chapter 19 should not be assigned for injuries that occur during, or as a result of, a medical intervention. Assign the appropriate complication code(s). (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
content.summary: Prohibition against using Chapter 19 injury codes for iatrogenic injuries, requiring complication codes instead (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
key_concepts: Iatrogenic injury exclusion from Chapter 19 (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
Medical intervention-related injuries (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
Complication code assignment requirement (Evidence: pg no: 79, L39)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Injury codes from Chapter 19 should not be assigned for injuries that occur during, or as a result of, a medical intervention (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
detailed_rules.explanation: Injuries caused by medical procedures require complication codes rather than standard injury codes (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assign the appropriate complication code(s) (Evidence: pg no: 79, L39)
detailed_rules.explanation: Complication codes are specifically designed for injuries resulting from medical interventions (Evidence: pg no: 79, L39)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify if injury occurred during or as result of medical intervention
Step 2: If iatrogenic, do not use Chapter 19 injury codes
Step 4: Assign complication code instead of injury code

code_ranges.description: Traumatic injury codes that should not be used for iatrogenic injuries (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
code_ranges.requirement: Do not use for medical intervention-related injuries
usage_rules: Exclude iatrogenic injuries from this range (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient develops injury during surgical procedure
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Accidental laceration of organ during surgical procedure
step_by_step: Step 1: Recognize injury occurred during medical intervention
Step 2: Do not assign Chapter 19 injury code
Step 3: Locate appropriate surgical complication code

correct_coding.rationale: Iatrogenic injuries require complication codes, not injury codes (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Chapter 19 codes are prohibited for iatrogenic injuries
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using injury codes for medical intervention complications

warnings: Never use Chapter 19 injury codes for iatrogenic injuries (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
best_practices: Always determine if injury is related to medical intervention before coding (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
common_mistakes: Using injury codes for surgical complications (Evidence: pg no: 79, L38-L39)
tips: Look for complication codes when injury occurs during medical care (Evidence: pg no: 79, L39)
implementation_notes: Requires careful review of circumstances surrounding injury
clinical_context: Common in surgical and procedural settings
